Sure, here are some examples of collaborations among Malaysian businesses and with external partners to strengthen their sustainability efforts:

1. Palm oil sustainability - The Malaysian Palm Oil Council (MPOC) has collaborated with international NGOs such as WWF and Rainforest Alliance to implement sustainability standards and certification for the palm oil industry in Malaysia. These efforts have promoted sustainable palm oil practices while also creating social and economic benefits for local communities.

2. Solar energy initiatives - Malaysian utility provider, Tenaga Nasional Berhad (TNB), has partnered with various businesses to promote the use of solar energy. One such collaboration is with Malaysia Airports Holdings Berhad (MAHB) to install solar panels at airports across the country, reducing carbon emissions and improving energy efficiency.

3. Circular economy - The Waste Management Association of Malaysia (WMAM) has worked with businesses to develop circular economy programs, including waste reduction and recycling initiatives. One example is the collaboration between WMAM and the Global Environment Centre (GEC) to launch a pilot project for organic waste recycling in the Klang Valley region.

4. Sustainable transportation - Malaysian car manufacturer, Proton, has collaborated with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in the US to develop more fuel-efficient cars. This partnership has helped Proton to reduce carbon emissions and improve fuel efficiency while also expanding its market reach.

These are just a few examples of how Malaysian businesses have collaborated with each other and with external partners to strengthen their sustainability efforts. Such initiatives help to promote sustainable economic growth while also addressing current environmental and social challenges.
